title: Can't compile solc version "^0.8.9"

body: If I use Remix and attach to my Web3 injected, connected to my blockchain, the deploy of the contract work well

Hm, interesting. If you've previously gotten this to work, you might try removing the `^`, since that causes Truffle to look for a later compatible version on the internet. I just tried this locally and it worked fine for me, so maybe this was just a temporary problem due to network conditions.

The other thing you could try is to set `docker: true` alongside `version: ...`, since that will have Truffle download the solc Docker container, rather than the JS-compiled distribution.

Sorry about this, and thank you for reporting this issue!
(I do notice that [this PR of mine](https://github.com/trufflesuite/truffle/pull/4420) is failing for similar reasons, so I'll be looking into this one way or another)

Mmmh very strange, in my MacBook Pro 13 m1 work, in my 16 not.. I am not using docker with truffle.

"Error: Could not find a compiler version matching 0.8.9. Please ensure you are specifying a valid version, constraint or build in the truffle config. Run `truffle compile --list` to see available versions."

I in my MacBook Pro m1 with sudo no work, but is very strange, I think is a strange problem with permission @gnidan please check, thanks
We're hard at work digging into this problem! Trying very hard to fix this in time for this week's release. Sorry everyone!

@thedarkknight197 and @pguso can you try Truffle v5.4.18? We're having a hard time reproducing this issue (the failing PRs seem to be unrelated).

I'd recommend uninstalling Truffle first, just to be safe:
```console
npm uninstall -g truffle
npm install -g truffle@5.4.18
```

@pguso I don't know if you're also using babel in your truffle-config like that, but @thedarkknight197 maybe try commenting out those two lines and see if it works any better for you?

Also, does this only happen when you run `truffle migrate`, or does `truffle compile` also fail? (And I guess, is it only a problem if you're migrating to `--network=live`?)

Any additional information you can provide would be helpful! Thank you

MacOS 12.0
MacBook Pro (14-inch, 2021) 
Apple M1 Max

Some more information, to the extent it is helpful:

I originally was not able to `npm install -g truffle`, so I used `sudo`. On further reflection and reading about how one is *not* supposed to `sudo npm install`, I did my best to uninstall `node` and used `homebrew` to reinstall it.

There's a chance that original `sudo npm install -g truffle` command is still causing issues, so wanted to mention it.

Oh! Could be that sudo is causing issues. Can you `ls -l ~/Library/Preferences/truffle-nodejs/compilers/node_modules/` please? That's where Truffle keeps its cache of compilers on Mac. It's possible that this directory got created owned by root, and now Truffle can't read from it.

Yep, returns:

```
total 24216
-rw-r--r--  1 root  staff  12394706 Nov 13 13:15 soljson-v0.5.16+commit.9c3226ce.js
```

Nice! Something to go off of. Try deleting Truffle's whole directory there:
```console
rm -rf ~/Library/Preferences/truffle-nodejs
```

You'll need to add `sudo` there, naturally :)

(and please never give Truffle super-user permissions, we don't want 'em!)

That was it. Removed that directory and was able to compile.

I, and @thedarkknight197 as well possibly given their `config` is very similar to mine, was following a tutorial that literally said you may have an issue with `npm install` and to use `sudo` in this case. I did it without thinking. Now hoping I don't need to reinstall the OS lol.

Bingo! I just reproduced the issue by `chown`ing that to `root`. Alright, @thedarkknight197 and @pguso please let us know if this fixes the problem for you as well.

Thanks for your help @maks-p and all.

(And stay tuned for a `truffle doctor` command, since @cds-amal just came up with the idea to automatically diagnose these sorts of issues ;)

> Bingo! I just reproduced the issue by `chown`ing that to `root`. Alright, @thedarkknight197 and @pguso please let us know if this fixes the problem for you as well.
>

Yes the command ```rm -rf ~/Library/Preferences/truffle-nodejs``` solves it for me. Thank you and the others helping to find a solution. I am happy that I can use truffle on my Air now.

Just for a little bit more context, `~/Library/Preferences/truffle-nodejs` is the folder in which Truffle stores user settings and, more importantly, the cache of Solidity compilers. I'm not sure why this would fix your issue but glad it resolved it!

Hi @eggplantzzz !

A colleague ran into this issue today and [this](https://github.com/trufflesuite/truffle/issues/4431#issuecomment-1108053572) ended up being the solution.

My hunch is that `truffle` was trying to read from the cache and needing `sudo` privileges to do so.

cc @gnidan @cds-amal

i changed the ownership of ~/.config/truffle-nodejs and it worked
chown userName -R ~/.config/truffle-nodejs
in my case the problem was that the file was locked to use only by root even though i never installed truffle using sudo

Hi @CruzMolina !

> A colleague ran into this issue today and [this](https://github.com/trufflesuite/truffle/issues/4431#issuecomment-1108053572) ended up being the solution.
> 
> My hunch is that `truffle` was trying to read from the cache and needing `sudo` privileges to do so.
> 

Your hunch is correct. We've seen this with *nix systems  due to root privileges unnecessarily applied. For example, using sudo with node package managers, or with `npm install`. 

You should ask your colleague to run [npm doctor](https://docs.npmjs.com/cli/v6/commands/npm-doctor) to validate their environment.

> i changed the ownership of ~/.config/truffle-nodejs and it worked 
> `chown userName -R ~/.config/truffle-nodejs` in my case the problem was that the file was locked to use only by root even though i never installed truffle using sudo

Truffle would use the privileges it inherited from the shell. I recommend you use [npm doctor](https://docs.npmjs.com/cli/v6/commands/npm-doctor) to verify its basic requirements are met.
